div1.head: Military Orders for Adolph F. Springer, August 24, 1900 [selected pages]
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 2 - 1900
Springer

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 199. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, August 24, 1900.

1. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Acting
Hospital Steward Walter B. Pettingill, Hospital Corps, Fort
Wadsworth, New York, will when relieved by an acting hos-
pital steward be discharged from the Army, by way of favor,
by the commanding officer of his station. This soldier is not
entitled to travel-pay.

2. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Frank Wiselogel, Troop B, 8th Cavalry, Fort Riley, Kansas,
having enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged with-
out honor from the Army by the commanding officer of his
station. Under paragraph 1386 of the Regulations this soldier
is not entitled to pay or allowances, and final statements, ex-
cept for deposits, shall not be furnished him.

3. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, 1st Class
Sergeant Frank P. Turner, Signal Corps, now on furlough at
Huron, South Dakota, from the Division of Cuba, is relieved
from duty in that division and will on or before expiration of
furlough report to the commanding officer, Fort Sheridan,
Illinois, to relieve 1st Class Sergeant John F. Dillon, Signal
Corps. Sergeant Dillon when thus relieved will be sent to
San Juan, Porto Rico. He will report upon his arrival to the
signal officer, Department of Porto Rico, to relieve 1st Class
Sergeant Stephen E. Karigan, Signal Corps. Sergeant Kari-
gan when thus relieved will be sent to the Signal Corps Post,
Fort Myer, Virginia. He will report upon his arrival to the
commanding officer of that post for duty.

4. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
George L. Thompson, Troop A, 5th Cavalry, Fort Huachuca,
Arizona Territory, is transferred to the Hospital Corps. Upon
receipt of this order at the post the commanding officer will
order him to report to the surgeon for duty at the hospital.

5. The resignation of Cadet Alexander L. L. de St. Aubin, 4th
Class, U. S. Military Academy, is accepted by the Secretary of
War.

6. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
5
office, will proceed to St. Paul, Minnesota, and report in per-
son to the commanding general, Department of Dakota, for
assignment to duty as chief surgeon of that department, to
relieve Colonel Joseph P. Wright, assistant surgeon general,
U. S. Army. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public
service.

24. By direction of the Secretary of War, leave of absence
for one month on account of sickness is granted Acting As-
sistant Surgeon Joseph J. Curry, U. S. Army.

25. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Adolph F. Springer, Troop M, 7th Cavalry, Havana, Cuba, is
transferred to the Hospital Corps and assigned to duty at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba. He will be sent to that station
and will report upon his arrival to the commanding officer
for duty.
✓

26. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Charles V. Hoffman, Company M, 5th Infantry, now on duty
at the recruiting station, Nos. 110 and 111 Cheesman Block,
17th and Larimer streets, Denver, Colorado, is transferred to
the general service and assigned to duty at his present station.

27. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Benjamin C. French, Troop M, 9th Cavalry, Fort Apache,
Arizona Territory, is transferred to the Hospital Corps.
Upon the receipt of this order at the post the commanding
officer will order him to report to the surgeon for duty at
the hospital.

28. By direction of the Secretary of War, 2d Lieutenant
Henry C. Merriam, recently appointed, with rank from August
20, 1900 (from sergeant, Battery H, 6th U. S. Artillery), is
assigned to the 18th U. S. Infantry, and after accepting his
appointment will proceed to join his regiment. He will be
assigned to a company by his regimental commander. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

29. By direction of the Secretary of War, the extension of
leave of absence on surgeon's certificate of disability granted
Major Louis Brechemin, surgeon, U. S. Army, in Special
Order, No. 140, June 15, 1900, from this office, is further
extended two months on surgeon's certificate of disability.
